sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russia promises to scale down operations in Kyiv and northern Ukraine at the latest round of peace talks in a first glimmer of hope for a reduction of violence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In Mykolaiv, a Russian strike batters a government building as people head to work, killing civilians and leaving others trapped under the rubble.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: killing civilians and leaving others trapped under the rubble.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Here in the Cube, we take a look at reports of war crimes committed by Ukrainian soldiers on Russian prisoners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And police in the UK hand out around 20 fines in relation to parties held at the Prime Minister's residence and government offices while the country was in lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Turkey says that significant progress has been made between Ukraine and Russia following a further round of peace talks in Istanbul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Previous negotiations between the two sides failed to make any breakthrough with the war now into its second month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But Moscow has made what appears to be its first major concession by announcing a reduction of military activity around Kyiv. The Russian delegation says the move is in response to Ukraine taking positive steps towards a non-aligned status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Taking into account the principles discussed during today's meeting, Taking into account the principles discussed during today's meeting, the Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation decided to cut back military activity in the direction of Kyiv and Chernihiv to increase mutual trust and create the necessary conditions for further negotiations and achieving the ultimate goal of agreeing and signing the above agreement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Ukrainian delegation says that a draft agreement has been negotiated that would seek Kyiv's security guaranteed by neighbouring countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This would-be agreement states that if Ukraine is a target of any military aggression or any attack, we will be entitled to hold consultations within three days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: If consultation fails to bring about the diplomatic resolution of the issue, the guarantor country should provide us with military assistance, weapons, and we do not rule out the possibility of closing the sky over Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Monitoring those peace talks in Turkey as well as the situation on the ground in Ukraine is our correspondent Sasha Vakulina.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Sasha, to be frank, I guess to start off with, I think it's fair to say over the past few weeks, peace talks have yielded, well, not much progress. Is that changing now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Absolutely. The expectations were almost at zero today as well, right? Nobody expected a ceasefire or any kind of peace agreement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It is fair to say that this is the most significant diplomatic moment since the beginning of the invasion in terms of the two sides talking and negotiating now russia said that now they will drastically reduce combat operations around kiev and chernihev as you said this is interesting because over the past couple of days we have seen russian troops there in the area in the northern part of ukraine not being able to gain more territories there there's been also some heavy fighting happening and this is where Ukrainian troops also started their counter-offensive these are the northern Northwest areas from Kyiv yet to see what's going to happen to it from the east of Kyiv and also the southern part of Kyiv from that direction Chernihiv of course is another very complicated situation there's still around direction. Chernihiv, of course, is another very complicated situation. There are still around thousands and thousands of people who are still there. It's over 100,000 people who are still there that are trapped. And this is the situation that is rather close to the one in Mariupol of humanitarian catastrophe. People who do not have electricity, they don't have food, they don't have water, and the humanitarian corridors didn't really work well enough for these people to be evacuated. Also, Ukrainian negotiators said that based on today's talks, they believe there was enough material in the current Ukrainian proposals to warrant a meeting between Zelensky and Russia's President Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: As you know, Zelensky has been saying from the very beginning that he is ready to sit down with Putin to negotiate face to face.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, we're now waiting to hear from Moscow, from Vladimir Putin, whether he is ready for that meeting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So as you say, Sasha, in that holding pattern now, essentially of waiting at the same time the potential for a reduction of military activity in Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But as you've also pointed out, that is not the whole story of the whole of the country you know thinking for example about that significant attack that we saw this morning in mykolaiv certainly there was this attacker would happen right before nine o'clock in the morning and the building of the regional administration attacked now the timing here is important also because this is the beginning of the day this is when people just started their work day or were coming to work right before nine o'clock.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And this is documented and the video is released and it's verified.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And this is what Volodymyr Zelensky had to say about that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This morning, Russian missiles hit one of our southern cities, Mykolaiv, a shipbuilding city, an absolutely peaceful city which dreamed of only one thing, to regain its place at the center of shipbuilding in the Black Sea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Following this strike, the regional administration building was destroyed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: As far as we know now, seven people were killed, 22 were wounded, and people are still going through the rubble.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Mykolaiv is half a million people population city on the Black Sea coast. It's a huge city which has been resisting so far and defending itself. It's also a crucial city when it comes to the Russian troops' movement from the south in the region of Kherson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Only via Mykolaiv region they hoped and they tried a few times to get to Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That was their way there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So Mykolaiv itself was attacked today, but this is also the road to Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So when it comes to there is some reduction, as they promised to have it around Kiev and Chernivtsi, but we still have the south, we have the east, and of course, we have the southeast with Mariupol. Absolutely important to look at all of those movements across the country, as you say, Sasha. Thank you, as ever, for your analysis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, also tracking those talks for us, our Russia correspondent Galina Polonskaya, who joins us now galina we understand that the russian chief negotiator has said they are ready to consider speeding up those face-to-face potential for a face-to-face meeting between president putin and zelensky but with the caveat that first a draft peace agreement is needed and that's not going to be easy is it exactly helen actually vladimir medinsky the chief russia's negotiator explained how russia sees this meeting he says that said that uh it could only happen the same day when the foreign ministers of two countries meet to initial the agreement between russia and ukraine meaning that the uh wording of the agreement should be already confirmed by both sides.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And after he said that in that case, the presidents could meet also there to resolve the remaining issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So the process is not going to be easy now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The proposals of Ukraine are going to be reported to president putin and medinsky today for example mentioned the issue of crimea and sevastopol as we know ukraine suggests to put it aside it promises not to try to get it back by military means but only by political ones and that the process could last for 15 years so medinsky underlined that this is only what Ukraine wants to see, but he said that it is no way representing Russia's position.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But on the other hand, for the first time, Russia said that this meeting is an option.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Just yesterday we heard from our foreign minister that it would be counterproductive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But at the same time, it is clear that now the decisions will be taken in Kiev and Ukraine and what we are in Kiev and Moscow and what we have seen today are the first concrete steps let's say so how have those first concrete steps how those latest developments gone down in Russia How have those latest developments gone down in Russia? Well, actually Russia's media and politicians are discussing Russia's announcement, which was mentioned by you and Sasha.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russia promised to drastically reduce its military activity near Ukrainian cities, and it was announced by Russia's deputy defense minister, who was there and he said that it was done to increase mutual trust to achieve peace as soon as possible and that's what some Russian media are saying state media of course but some analysts programming analysts say that actually it was something that Russia would have done in any case that that's this strategy and today for the first time Helen we have heard from Russia's defense minister Sergei Shigul he proclaimed Russia's main goal for the first time saying quote that the girl is the liberation of the bus and that's what the politicians are saying and some papers also speak about the Crimea question one of them says that Kyiv's proposal to discuss the status of Crimea will obviously not find even the slightest understanding in Moscow all right Galina Polonskaya good to talk to you thanks Galina well I want to bring in Ina Suf now, who is a member of the Ukrainian parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: She joins me from Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ina, so good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much for taking the time and for being with us this evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I want to begin just by asking you what the latest is where you are.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, while I was waiting to go on air, I was actually hearing some explosions just northwest of the city. So that is the de-escalation for you that you can well, that you read on the Russian news, but it's not actually happening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So it's still a very real war around Kyiv. We still got about four or five air raid alerts during since the night here in Kyiv. That means that the missiles have been set to target Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They have not hit anything here, but it is still happening. It is still here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And that actually coincided about half an hour ago. That was yet another explanation by Mr. Medinsky, who is chairing the Russian delegation. And he says, and I quote, de-escalation in the Kyiv and Chernihiv direction does not mean a ceasefire.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So that is what we are seeing right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: As we speak, I'm hearing explosions northwest of the city right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ina, I wanted to ask you more about that, because talking about that de-escalation that's promised in Kyiv and Chernihiv to boost trust in these talks, what trust do you have that in the coming hours that that will come to pass?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Zero, unfortunately.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I wish I could say something else, but we have zero reasons for trusting whatever the Russians are saying.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We should learn this lesson by now, and the world should learn this lesson by now, is that those people are lying all the time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Like a week before the beginning of the full-scale war, Putin gave an interview saying that he is not planning to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Two weeks into the war, Lavrov went to the foreign minister, foreign journalists, and said that they had never attacked Ukraine to begin with. So, those are the people who are lying all the time. And so that is why making any deals with them is so very complicated. And that is why Ukrainian population in general is rather pessimistic about the results of those talks because we have no reason to trust people who have been killing us actively for one month, but then also you have to remember that we are at war with Russia since 2014.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ina, I want to say thanks for taking the time to talk to us, especially when you're hearing explosions nearby.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And I also want to ask more about your role as a lawmaker, because President Zelensky has said that he's ready to discuss neutrality and staying out of NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But he says it would be up to Ukrainians to vote on it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And as a lawmaker, what do you think the people you represent would vote for, and also on the issue of the status of the Donbass region if it came down to it? Well, first of all, in terms of neutrality, you have to realize that in 2014, when Putin annexed Crimea and started the war in Donbass, which has killed 14,000 people as of January 2022, we were officially a neutral state in 2014. And that gave us no guarantee from Russian aggression against our country. And trust me, people here do remember that very well. So, and that is why right now the support for NATO membership of Ukraine is as high as it has never been before. It is around 80 percent right now. In all regions of Ukraine, everybody is saying that we need very firm guarantees of our security that will actually make sure that we are not attacked yet again in a month, a year, eight years from any deal taking place here right now. And that is something that we really, really want to avoid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: No, of course, we want the war to stop right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Trust me, I wish I could bring my son back home today and just forget about the war taking place to an extent that it is possible at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But I don't want the war to restart in a month or a year or two years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And I don't want my son to inherit the war as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And that is why we have to make realistic deals where our security will be guaranteed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And right now we are not getting those from Russians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We are just getting promises which are not being kept.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Can I ask you, who do you think, which country would provide that security guarantee when NATO membership has already proved to be such a thorny issue?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, I still believe that we should continue knocking on the doors of NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I think that we have proven to be a very strong army.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We have proven to be a democratic state.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We don't have a reason why not take us into NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So we have to keep on knocking on those doors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I'm sure, absolutely sure about that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But other than that, we need guarantees from the major powers and the real guarantees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Because we were given guarantees in 1994 when we gave up our nuclear weapon by the United States, by the United Kingdom and by, ironically, Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We were promised that if we are attacked, those countries will protect us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And we are seeing that that is not happening now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I mean, we are getting some weapon and and some you know equipment from the uk and the us but that is not really what we need right now right and that is why we we need very tough guarantees of our security and i still believe and the majority absolute majority of the ukrainian population believe that nato would be the best guarantee for our security and there there is no other mechanism for guarantees of security that exists in this world today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: All right.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ines Ussun, a member of the Ukrainian parliament, joining me from Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much for talking to us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do take care.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you for having me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you, Elena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's ombudsperson claims that Moscow has forcibly moved 402,000 people, including 84,000 children, to Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But the Kremlin denies those claims, instead saying it's relocated the people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So for more, let's go over to Brussels. We can speak to Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you. We've been talking, I guess, for weeks about people fleeing Ukraine, heading into EU member states but these are reports about a significant number of people moving heading into Russia under worrying circumstances. What more can you tell us? Yeah that's right we saw at the start of the war in February evidence of people being forced to be displaced to Russia that's what the reports were and I caught up with the Ukrainian ombudsman today here in Brussels who's here to discuss the various war evidence of war crimes taking place in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And she told me that the figure of people being forcibly displaced to Russia from Ukraine is over 400,000.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And she told me about a specific family.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: On March 9th, the Russian occupying forces came to their home and took them away to the booth that on the bus where there were also other people that were gathered on filtration camps in the Donetsk region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And they, while those buses, they were transferred to the territory of city of Taganrog back Відтворені баси пересувалися до території Таганрогу, де вони залишилися з 9 до 15 липня.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Вони залишилися в кінцернаті, лягли на території, включно з цією родиною та іншими людьми.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: В місті Таганрог, де ми були, вона з'їхала на рейвістанцію, з'їхала на трені і з'їхала до села Суздал у Володимирському регіоні.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: І зі маючого 20-го ми не маємо більше контакту, ніж зі своїми родинами. Вони могли б подумати, більше зв'язку з ними нема. person is to track cases of human rights abuses is to collect evidence was she able to speak more broadly to what they've been able to collect so far yes she she talked about well obviously the forcible displacement of civilians in occupied territory is a grave breach of the Geneva Convention so that's a war crime she also discussed the situation in Mariupol the intensive shelling the targeting of civilians civilian objects the targeting of civilians, civilian objects, the targeting of children. She also accused the Russian army of stealing the uniforms of Ukrainian soldiers and essentially pretending or masquerading as Ukrainian soldiers. So she said there is a long list of war crimes that Russia has committed and they intend to use this for eventually a sort of war crimes court crimes tribunal and a case at the International Court of Justice. Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right Shona thanks for bringing that story to our attention. Shona Murray there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well British police have issued fines to 20 people who attended gatherings at Downing Street that

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: broke Covid lockdown rules. It's part of an investigation into 12 events that happened during lockdown, three of which the Prime Minister attended.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The identities of those fined isn't known.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A spokesman for Boris Johnson says he's not among the group, but reiterated that if the Prime Minister is fined, it will be made public.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, the Partygate scandal, as it's known, caused huge anger among the public and within parliament with calls for Johnson to resign. Ukraine and Russia have launched investigations

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: into a graphic video allegedly showing Ukrainian forces mistreating Russian prisoners of war and here's Matthew in the cube with more. Well Helena throughout the war we've seen multiple examples of misinformation and propaganda from both Russia and Ukraine, as well as allegations of war crimes that the International Criminal Court are investigating.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Over the weekend a number of graphic videos appeared on social media.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We won't be showing you those, however, they claim to show Ukrainian soldiers torturing Russian prisoners of war by shooting them in the leg after they had been captured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The clips were shared widely on various platforms, including by a number of pro-Russian accounts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said that the images were monstrous.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: However, the validity and the contents of this video still needs to be verified.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But here are a number of things that we do know.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Independent fact-checkers have found that the videos were filmed to the southeast of the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, an area that we know was recently recaptured by Ukrainian forces. And what's more, the presidential advisor to President Volodymyr Zelensky has issued a reminder to Ukrainian defense forces in an Instagram video saying that Ukraine treats prisoners of war under the Geneva Convention regardless of any personal emotional motivations. An investigation into the video has been launched.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now on the other hand you have the commander-in-chief of Ukraine's armed forces who has dismissed those videos. He has instead claimed that Russia has been filming propaganda videos to try and discredit Ukrainian forces and their attitude to prisoners of war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And since then, another viral image has appeared online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This letter claims to show Russia authorizing the filming of these kind of propaganda videos.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: However, there are doubts about the validity of this claim.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It is reported to have been signed by Dmitry Bulgakov, a deputy to the Russian Defence Minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: However, if you compare this signature on this image to another of Bulgakov's, reportedly from 2020, you can see there are differences between the two.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And what's more, fact-checkers say that this signature on this reported letter has instead appeared elsewhere on the internet in an unrelated Russian personality quiz.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So therefore, there are doubts about the validity of this letter, instead appeared elsewhere on the internet in an unrelated Russian personality quiz.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So therefore there are doubts about the validity of this letter which claims that Russia has authorised the filming of propaganda videos.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: However Helen, one thing is clear and that is that both Russia and Ukraine have launched an investigation into those allegations of war crimes and that very graphic video that appeared over the weekend.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Alright Matthew, doing the forensic work of fact-checking there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You're up to date. Bye for now.
